Award.AwardTitle: Towards a Better Representation of Cloud-Aerosol Interactions in the Community Earth System Model: With Applications to Heterogeneous Nucleation of Cirrus, and Aerosol-Cloud Intera
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clouds and aerosols play a major role in the Earth's radiative budgets and in the hydrological cycle. It is a challenge problem to realistically represent/simulate clouds and cloud-aerosol interactions in global models of the Earth's climate system because they are very complex and usually much smaller than the typical tens of kilometer sized grid cells in current global models. In order to limit computing costs, the present Community Earth System Model (CESM), which is one of the nation's leading global models, uses a minimalist representation of clouds by computing only their mean particle size and their condensed water mass. These simplifications lead to a vast expansion of tuning parameters whose values are not well defined. As a result, the current CESM cloud model predicts liquid cloud particle sizes that differ greatly from those observed by satellite. The work replaces the CESM liquid cloud model with one that fully tracks the range of particles sizes in the clouds. With full knowledge of the particle sizes much more complete and realistic cloud physics will be implemented in the model, and the number of tunable, poorly defined parameters will be reduced. The new model will also be used to improve the parameterization of physical mechanisms. Another goal of the work is to link aerosols to the ice cloud model, and apply the ice cloud model to determine the role of new ice particle formation, particularly involving organic aerosols, in controlling cloud properties. By utilizing the size resolved liquid and ice models, the study will evaluate the aerosol-cloud climate forcing, one of the most uncertain factors in climate modeling.

Cloud properties and aerosol-cloud interactions are among the greatest uncertainties in climate modeling. By improving the physics used to simulate clouds and their interactions with aerosols the uncertainties may be reduced. This project will improve representations of both ice and liquid clouds in CESM, test these changes against data mainly from satellites, and apply the models to well-defined, testable projects involving cloud-aerosol interactions. This project will integrate research and education by advancing discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning; broaden participation of underrepresented groups in the Physical Sciences by involving female graduate students; enhance the national infrastructure for research and education by further developing the CESM model; and, provide benefits to society by reducing uncertainty in aerosol radiative climate forcing resulting from a better representation of interactions between clouds and aerosols as well as by improving national tools to address such issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this work were: 1) To compare simulations using the sectional ice cloud model that we developed in the NSF/DOE Community Earth System Model version 1 (CESM1) with observations of cirrus clouds; 2) to extend the sectional ice cloud model so that it fully interacts with the modal aerosol model in CESM1; 3) to explore the relative importance of homogeneous nucleation and heterogeneous nucleation for cirrus clouds in the tropical upper troposphere; and 4) to implement a sectional liquid cloud model in CESM1 to augment the two-moment cloud model currently used in CESM1.

We met the first goal in the paper “An evaluation of the representation of Tropical Tropopause cirrus in the CESM/CARMA model using satellite and aircraft observations”, (C.  Maloney, C. Bardeen, O. B. Toon, E. Jensen, S.Woods, T. Thornberrry, L. Pfister, G. Diskin, and T. Paul Bui), J. Geophys. Res.: Atmospheres, 124, 8659-8687. 2019.https://doi.org/10.1029/2018JD029720.  The paper successfully compared simulations with the sectional ice model with data from satellites and from the ATTREX aircraft field program.

Goals 2 and 3 were met with the paper “Improved ice cloud representation in the CARMA cirrus model using interactive sulfates and a basic heterogeneous nucleation parameterization for dust”, (C. Maloney, C. Bardeen, O. B. Toon, J. Kay), submitted to J Geophys. Res. 2021.) It shows that homogeneous nucleation dominates in regions colder than the -40C, which occurs mostly above 7 km.  However, heterogeneous nucleation is important for latitudes north of 30N where dust particles are present part of the year.  A major discovery as part of this work is found in “Efficient In‐Cloud Removal of Aerosols by Deep Convection”, (Yu et al. ) Geophys Res. Letters, 46, 1–9, doi:10.1029/2018GL080544, 2019. They show that almost all models of aerosols have been incorrectly simulating dust, sea salt, black carbon and related materials in the upper troposphere due to incorrect assumptions in convective transport simulations.  Concentration errors in the upper troposphere have been from factors of 10-1000 due to this problem.  As a result, many models have greatly overestimated the amount of dust at high altitude, and therefore overestimated its importance as ice nuclei for cloud formation.  This paper was recognized by Geophys. Res. Lett. as one of the most downloaded papers of 2019.

            To meet goal 4, we placed a sectional liquid cloud model in CESM2, which can be used as an alternative to the standard cloud model in CESM2. Clouds are a challenge to simulate in global climate models because they are very complex and usually much smaller than the typical hundred-kilometer sized grid cells in current global models.  In order to limit computing costs, the present NSF/DOE Community Earth System Model (CESM2) uses a minimalist representation of clouds by computing only their mean particle size and their condensed water mass.  With this minimalist representation, the model must greatly simplify the physics in the computer code.  The simplifications require many tuning parameters.  Some of these, such as particle size distribution shapes, can be based on data.  However, others such as rain production rates are parameterized, rather than being based on microphysical equations.  As a result, if the parameterization must be adjusted it is done by model tuning rather than changes in physically based microphysical parameters. It has been found that the standard CESM2 cloud model is responsible for most of the significant increase in the sensitivity of climate to increased CO2 relative to CESM1.  We replaced the CESM2 standard liquid cloud model with one that fully tracks the range of particles sizes in the clouds.  With full knowledge of the particle sizes much more complete and realistic cloud physics has been implemented in the model, and tunable, poorly defined parameters have been reduced.

            This work contributed to our knowledge of how clouds form and how they impact the climate.  In addition, the work expanded the capabilities of the NSF supported Community Earth System Model.   When fully developed our new cloud model will provide an additional choice for climate modelers. The Community Earth System Model is the major climate model in the U.S. open to all researchers.  Others climate modelers will therefore benefit from our cloud model development once the model is fully on the distributed branch.  Climate modeling is essential to understand the evolving climate due to greenhouse gases, and also due to other events such as volcanic eruptions, nuclear conflicts, air pollution, geoengineering and others.  Having an advanced cloud model will make these simulations more reliable.  Our cloud model also has capabilities not found in the current CESM2 model, opening up new types of simulations.

            In this work we trained one graduate student who received a PhD and is now working at the NOAA ESRL labs.  We also trained another female student who continues working on her PhD degree.  Currently a PhD Research Associate is working with this model.
